node.title: Solving the mystery of the HMAS Sydney II's 'unknown sailor'
node.alt: A senior woman with grey hair looking out to sea.
node.description: The body of just one of the 645 World War II seaman lost at sea aboard the HMAS Sydney II was ever discovered. Now there is hope the man's identityÂ will finally be revealed.
node.content:
["The identity of the only body ever recovered from the lost war ship HMAS Sydney II is expected to be announced tomorrow on the 80th anniversary of the ship's final battle.", "A seaman, known as the Unknown Sailor, was discovered on Christmas Island after the HMAS Sydney\u00a0II sank in a World War II battle on November 19, 1941.", "His grave was found in 2006 but it is only now that technological advances are thought to have helped reveal his identify.", "HMAS Sydney researcher Glenys MacDonald was instrumental in helping discover the sailor's grave and hopes announcing the man's identity will bring closure to the man's family.", "\"In some ways, not knowing meant he represented the entire crew. But we've got to remember there's families out there and hopefully one family will have the answers.\"", "", "
HMAS Sydney II portside displaying camouflage.(Supplied: Sea Power Centre \u2013 Australia)
", "
Final battle
", "The HMAS Sydney II and its crew of 645 were darlings of the Australian war fleet as they cruised the Western Australian coast in November 1941.", "Their loss in a battle with the German cruiser HSK Kormoran devastated a nation and sparked decades of research, speculation and controversy about\u00a0where the ship had\u00a0sunk.", "While some 315 of the Kormoran's 393 officers and crew survived the loss of their ship, none of the HMAS Sydney II's men were found \u2014 except for the body of one sailor who washed up in an invertible life raft\u00a0on\u00a0Christmas Island, eight days after the battle.", "The sailor was buried by locals and largely forgotten. Later, in 1950, a man named Brian O'Shannassy took a photo of the gravesite. The Navy subsequently attempted to find the lost grave \u2013 to no avail.", "Meanwhile\u00a0Mr O'Shannassy\u00a0handed the photo to Ms MacDonald, who had\u00a0become passionate about finding the HMAS Sydney II's final resting place after hearing stories of her loss from locals in Western Australia.", "Using the photo, countless interviews and archival research across the globe to aid her case,\u00a0Ms MacDonald managed to convince the Navy to launch another search for the lost HMAS\u00a0Sydney sailor's grave.", "With Mr O'Shannassy in tow, naval officers\u00a0visited the site of the photo and dug five trenches \u2013 each one empty.", "They shared the devastating news with Ms MacDonald who again convinced them to keep looking \u2014 this time in a wider gap between the graves.", "Here, at last, they found the unmarked grave of the unknown sailor. His body was exhumed and studied in New South Wales. But at the time, the DNA extracted from a tooth provided no clues to his identity.", "In 2008, the man's body was buried in the closest Commonwealth war grave cemetery to the ship's final resting place \u2013 in the coastal city of Geraldton, Western Australia.", "", "
A burial party carries the coffin of an unknown serviceman from HMAS Sydney II into the Geraldton War Cemetery in 2008.\u00a0(AAP Image/Department of Defence: Jo Dilorenzo)
", "
Revealing the sailor's identify
", "Fast forward 80 years, and advances in DNA testing mean the sailor's identity may finally be revealed.", "\"It's been a slow, gradual process of elimination;\u00a0technology has come a long way and breakthroughs happen,\" Ms MacDonald said.", "\"I was lucky enough in be able to help in finding the (HMAS)\u00a0Sydney sailor and this is the last unknown \u2014 for me anyway.", "\"I've had all my questions that I've raised over the decades answered and this is the final answer, so I'm hoping when the announcement comes it will be what we all hope for.\""]
